prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
################################# # NGC 1068 HCN/HCO+ v2=1f J=4-3 # #################################
Basic observing parameters: For our observations of all molecular transition lines, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA)(C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: The observed peak flux of the possibly detected HCN v2=1f J=4-3 emission line is 10 mJy (Figure 4, rms noise level is 3 mJy).
HCN v2=1f J=4-3 and HCO+ v2=1f J=4-3 lines are simultaneously observable.
If HCO+ is vibrationally-excited to v2=1 in a similar way to HCN (case 1), then HCO+ v2=1f J=4-3 flux is expected to be 5 mJy, because the HCN-to-HCO+ flux ratio at v=0 is 2 (Krips et al. 2011). If HCN is more preferentially vibrationally-excited by infrared radiative pumping than HCO+ and HNC (case 2), then the HCO+ v2=1f J=4-3 flux is expected to be <5 mJy. To clearly distinguish between case 1 and 2, we set the noise level as 0.8 mJy. If we obtain no significant detection (<3 sigma) for the HCO+ v2=1f J=4-3 line in case 2, we can clearly differentiate the case 2 from case 1, and so can provide very strong observational constraints on whether infrared radiative pumping works in a similar manner for HCN and HCO+, or works effectively only for HCN.
The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that the required observing time will be 1.1 hr to achieve 1 sigma noise of 0.8 mJy for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use two spectral windows in USB to cover HCO+ v2=1f J=4-3 and HCN v2=1f J=4-3 + HCO+ J=4-3 lines at the same time. In LSB, we will use two spectral windows to cover continuum emission and H13CN J=4-3 (rest frequency = 345.3 GHz) + HC15N J=4-3 (344.2 GHz) lines.
Continuum observation in LSB is important to better understand the continuum emission, after correcting for serendipitously detected emission lines (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a,b,c).
H13CN and HC15N emission lines are expected to be optically-thin. Comparison of the H13CN and HC15N J=4-3 line fluxes with HCN J=4-3 (v=0) line flux can be used to confirm whether the HCN J=4-3 (v=0) line is optically-thick or not. This optical depth information for the HCN J=4-3 (v=0) line is important to quantitatively estimate the role of the infrared radiative pumping for HCN excitation, based on the flux comparison of the HCN v2=1f J=4-3 and HCN J=4-3 (v=0) emission lines (Sakamoto et al. 2010).
These are the reasons for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

############################ # NGC 1068 HNC v2=1f J=4-3 # ############################
Basic observing parameters: For our observations of all molecular transition lines, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA)(C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: The expected HNC v2=1f J=4-3 peak flux in case 1 is 5 mJy, because the HCN to HNC flux ratio at v=0 is typically 2 at LIRG's nuclei (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a,b,c). We set the requested 1 sigma noise level as 0.8 mJy. If we obtain no significant detection (<3 sigma) for HNC v2=1f J=4-3 line in case 2, we can clearly distinguish between case 1 and 2. The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that the required observing time will be 1.3 hr for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use two spectral windows in USB to cover HNC v2=1f J=4-3 and HNC J=4-3 lines at the same time. Additional two spectral windows in LSB will be used to better understand the continuum emission, after correcting for serendipitously detected emission lines (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a,b,c). In fact, our ALMA Cycle 0 data show discernible flux difference of the continuum emission between USB and LSB (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a,b,c). Continuum spectral index is useful to understand the physical origin of the continuum emission.
These are the reasons for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

################################# # NGC 1068 HCN/HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 # #################################
Basic observing parameters: For our observations of all molecular transition lines, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA)(C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: The expected HCN v2=1f J=3-2 flux is 5.5 mJy, if HCN is thermally excited at up to J=4-3 (J=3-2 flux is 9/16 of J=4-3) and if the HCN v2=1f to v=0 flux ratio is similar between J=4-3 and J=3-2. If HCN excitation is sub-thermal at J=4-3, the J=3-2 flux is larger than 9/16 of J=4-3 flux. Thus, the expected HCN v2=1f J=3-2 flux is >5.5 mJy
HCN v2=1f J=3-2 and HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 are simultaneously observable.
In case 1, the expected HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 flux is >2.7 mJy. We set the required 1 sigma noise level as 0.6 mJy. In the case of non-detection (case 2), we can clearly distinguish from case 1. The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that the required observing time will be 1.0 hr for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use three spectral windows in USB to cover HCN J=3-2, HCO+ J=3-2 + HCN v2=1f J=3-2, and HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time. This is the reason for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

############################ # NGC 1068 HNC v2=1f J=3-2 # ############################
Basic observing parameters: For our observations of all molecular transition lines, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA)(C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: The expected HNC v2=1f J=3-2 peak flux in case 1 is >2.7 mJy. We set the required 1 sigma noise as 0.6 mJy. In the case of non-detection (case 2), we can clearly distinguish from case 1. The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that the required observing time will be 1.0 hr for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use two spectral windows in USB to cover HNC v2=1f J=3-2 and HNC J=3-2 lines at the same time. Using two spectral windows in LSB, we will observe H13CN J=3-2 (259.0 GHz) and HC15N (258.2 GHz), to confirm whether the HCN J=3-2 line is optically-thick or not (Sakamoto et al. 2010).
These are the reasons for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose HCN/HCO+/HNC observations at vibrationally-excited and -ground levels, of the nearby bright AGN-dominated nucleus of NGC 1068. Our scientific goal is to estimate the strengths of vibrationally-excited emission lines of HCN/HCO+/HNC, and to clarify whether infrared radiative pumping indeed selectively boosts HCN emission, when compared to HCO+ and HNC. Detailed study of this prototypical pure AGN will play a crucial role to resolve the highly disputed issue of whether infrared radiative pumping is indeed important to enhance HCN emission in many AGNs. If the infrared radaitive pumping is ubiquitously at work for HCN excitation in AGNs, vibrationally excited HCN emission lines must be clearly detected in the NGC 1068 nucleus with ALMA. If these lines are not detected, ubiquitous role of infrared radiative pumping for enhanced HCN emission in AGNs is strongly ruled out. ALMA's high-spatial-resolution (<0.6 arcsec) is vital to probe only the AGN-dominated nuclear region, with minimum contamination from surrounding starburst activity in the host galaxy. ALMA's high-sensitivity (sub-mJy noise level) is indispensable to clearly distinguish between contradictory scenarios.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: This proposal is related to our Cycle 1 accepted program (2012.1.00034.S) (PI = Imanishi).

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Optical and Infrared Astronomy, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
School of Physical Sciences, Graduate University for Advanced Studies
Institute of Astronomy, University of Tokyo
